I don't think that such a policy is a good idea. Children who do something bad once aren't neccecarily bad - they may have made a mistake, done something by accident, or been wrongly judged. I once accidentally broke a window, for example.
 
 However, I do think that children who misbehave and break rules need to have something done about them. I live in England, where we don't have anything like this policy. There was a girl in my class called Emily, who cared nothing for school and regularly insulted, teased and bullied many members of the class. She had been in the junior school (our school is split into 2 sections, the 4 years under 11 and the 11 to 18) and had behaved the same way, yet when she had applied to join the senior school she was allowed to join even though she had that bad record. She wasn't expelled until Christmas of third year.
 
 So I think that zero tolerance is a bad thing, but being lax about bad behaviour isnt good either. I propose a middle path - perhaps three strikes would be good? What do other people thing about that?

Poet, your question is a good one. 
 
 Consider this. Zero tolerance that is applied logically. The chicken finger etc, would be instances of the zero tolerance policy applied innappropriately. It is certainly not a case of a child bringing a pretend weapon to school. However, suppose that this kid had been told repeatedly not to do that thing, had been talked to over a period of weeks and months, and then did it in front of the principal intentionally to get his goat. Expulsion may still be appropriate (based upon record etc) but would not be an example of zero tolerance. 
 
 I do think there should be zero tolerance of drugs or actual weapons brought on or used on school property. Use drugs in the bathroom, your out at least for a short time. Suspension may be a better compromise than expulsion. Grab a pencil and stab another kid with it, your out. (Used as a weapon rather than bringing a weapon).
 
 That is my take.
